captions.text:
Alright, I&#39;ve put up with this drought nonsense
for long enough, games industry, put something

new out or I&#39;m kicking this chair away right
now.
&quot;Alright, here&#39;s We Happy Few.

It&#39;s a procedurally generated - wait wait
wait stay on the chair!
It&#39;s also got a retro-futurist aesthetic.&quot;
Oh, well, man the fucking spunk pumps.
Everything&#39;s retro-futurist these days.

Bioshock was a wonderful thing to bring into
the world but the retro-futurist trend is
just getting silly now.

Did you all decide you were sick of hiring
concept artists so you went to your grandma&#39;s

basement and nicked an armful of Ideal Home
catalogues from the 70s?

But seriously though, We Happy Few does interest
me.

I know it&#39;s been on early access for what
is technically known as a &#39;yonk&#39; but it seemed

like it was going to have some kind of story
and I didn&#39;t want to spoil that for myself

while it was still at the puppet theatre stage
of development.

But what also interested me as a British person
was that it&#39;s an extremely British game set

in Britain where British characters do British
things and wait a minute what&#39;s that Canadian

flag doing sticking out of your tit-shaped
police helmet?

Oh right, forgive me, it&#39;s actually a Canadian
game setting out to be a love letter to retro
British culture.

So you know what that means, everyone, strap
in for a bunch of fucking Monty Python references.
But lets be fair.

We Happy Few is set in an alternative 60&#39;s
Britain inspired by the weirdly specific and

no less weirdly well-populated genre of retro
British dystopian fiction as seen in 1984,

Brave New World, A Clockwork Orange, The Prisoner,
V for Vendetta, and every panty-sloshing wet
dream Margaret Thatcher ever had.

And there is actually some very apt and intelligent
satire of the British national identity going

on here, as well as a load of NPCs with funny
accents quoting Monty bleeding Python at each
other.

In a world where Britain lost the second world
war, the people of the isolated city of Wellington

Wells are kept distracted from the nightmares
of past and present reality with a designer

drug that induces happiness, suppresses negative
memories, prevents childbirth and pairs well

with onion gravy, blimey, talk about science
fiction, my anti-depressants didn&#39;t do much
more than kill all my boners.

Everyone who can&#39;t or won&#39;t take the drug
gets exiled to a big meadow immediately outside

of town, which is pretty fucking weaksauce
as far as exile goes but I suppose that&#39;s

what happens when everyone in authority is
off their fucking tits all day.

This is that apt satire thing I was talking
about, because what this is is the British

characteristic of keeping a cheerful stiff
upper lip in times of crisis elevated to oppressive
fascist doctrine.

It&#39;s a theme that also comes up in the characterisation
of the protagonist, Arthur Hastings, who seems

to descend into fits of stammering anxiety
at the mere thought of &#39;causing a fuss&#39; and

apologises profusely every time he has to
kill someone or cuddle them to sleep.

And that&#39;s the quintessence of the Britain
I remember - the oppressive fascist state

doesn&#39;t come about because of internal strife
or military coup, it comes about largely because
nobody wanted to cause a fuss.

Arthur stops taking his pills when he starts
remembering his long-lost brother, and thus

begins a picaresque narrative in which we
explore the various workings of Wellington

Wells in pursuit of Arthur&#39;s quest to escape
it, the game being structured in true Bioshock-style

wherein every deceptively simple objective
has about five hundred hidden sub-objectives

so you&#39;ll get the chance to run errands through
all four corners of the earth and you can&#39;t

take a more direct path because that would
entail causing a fuss.

So We Happy Few could be considered an acid
test of sorts for procedural generation.

Yes, we&#39;ve all seen how procgen is very useful
in indie dungeon crawlers for creating theoretically

infinite levels, as long as you&#39;re fine with
having a theoretically infinite number of

rather hauntingly similar levels, but if you&#39;re
making a triple-A style immersive sim in your

Bioshock or Prey or Deus Ex kind of mold,
is it viable to procedurally generate the

hub world if you don&#39;t have the manpower to
design one manually because everyone&#39;s too

busy printing T-shirts for the kickstarter
backers?
And the answer to that is, no, you big twats.

Enticing as it may be to add game designer
to the list of jobs the corporate overlords

no longer have to pay someone to do, a computer
can&#39;t design a fun game unless a human tells

it what a fun game is and at that point the
human is being what we call a game designer.

So We Happy Few has its important fixed spots
and story locations and in between them is
a load of procedurally generated bugger all.

A quest places an objective marker about a
kilometre away.
I hike over to the marker.
Nothing happens in the meantime.

I skipped through a meadow and picked a few
flowers.

Oh, the hard boiled life of the defiant revolutionary
subversive.
I&#39;ve just had this really crazy idea, guys.

How about, instead of procedurally generating
an open world &#39;cos every game has to have

one and you need to keep up, you just restrict
the gameplay to the important fun parts and
cut out the travel time in between.

We could call them, I dunno, &#39;stages&#39; or &#39;levels&#39;
or &#39;chapters&#39; if you&#39;re pretentious.

That way there wouldn&#39;t be as much useless
boring bullshit.
Blimey, why has no one thought of this.

But even if you enjoy running across empty
meadows because you&#39;re a fucking horse, the

procgen might also be why the game&#39;s buggier
than a jungle explorer&#39;s sock drawer.

It was almost certainly the reason I could
turn a corner and find about fifty clones

of the same old lady standing around a section
of road having a Monty Python quote-off.

Mind you, I doubt it was the procedural level
design that was making half of them float

two feet off the ground and the other half
clip inside a wall.

I know I hate to cause a fuss but recoiling
through a wall while I&#39;m trying to beat you

to death with a cricket bat isn&#39;t just rude,
it&#39;s downright unsporting.

What were two years of development in early
access for if not fixing the fucking bugs?

Giving each other piggy back rides to the
Doctor Who marathons?

But all the bug spray in the world won&#39;t fix
the fact that it&#39;s not a very well-designed
game.

Having to weigh taking a happy drug to go
unnoticed against the risk of overdosing is

a solid enough mechanic, but in practise you
don&#39;t need to take happy drugs much at all.

Most of the happy drug detecting barriers
can be bypassed and people don&#39;t notice you

as long as you dress right and avoid jumping
onto cars while hooting like a gibbon but

even if you do cause the dreaded fuss and
the NPCs all close in drawing their frying

pans and sticks with copies of Wisden nailed
to the end, you can run faster than the world&#39;s

sexiest greyhound through a furry convention
and are surrounded by miles of procedurally
generated wilderness full of hiding spots.

Yes, your protagonist has Horizon Zero Dawn
syndrome and can only hide in one specific

kind of bush, but I still ended up uninterestedly
sprinting through all the areas straight to

the objectives because I knew all I had to
do afterwards was stand behind a moderately

large cat and all the guards and security
devices would forget about my existence entirely.

In brief, Wee Crappy Poo is a game with good
ideas buried under piles of rubbish for the
sake of openness.

Don&#39;t get me wrong, openness is good if one
happens to be a cake shop or a pair of legs,
just not so much if you&#39;re a tiger cage.
Or Margaret Thatcher&#39;s legs.
